Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Manufacturing of Bio-Inspired Polymer Micro/Nano-Fiber Arrays as New Gripping Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a pilot-scale production system and process to enable the large-scale fabrication of continuous arrays of elastomeric micro/nano-scale fibers with complex geometry. Inspired by hairs that occur naturally on gecko feet, these micro/nano-scale elastomeric fibers demonstrate strong adhesive, shear, and peel strengths over a wide range of test substrates. Unlike other classes of adhesives such as pressure-sensitive tapes, these biologically-inspired adhesives can be repeatedly used over thousands of test cycles with very little contamination and performance degradation over the material lifespan. However, this class of material has only been able to be fabricated through expensive micro/nano fabrication processes including photolithography, chemical etching, or time-consuming batch micro/nano molding processes. In this project, a pilot-scale manufacturing system will be constructed, optimized and evaluated. A roller-based molding and peeling process for high-speed, continuous, and large-area manufacturing of high aspect-ratio and three-dimensional micro/nano-scale fibers with a compliant backing layer will be developed using elastomer materials.

The broader/commercial impacts of this project will be the potential to provide a low-cost, high-volume process to mass produce continuous arrays of elastomeric micro/nano-scale fibers with complex geometry for applications in apparel, sporting equipment, healthcare, defense, industrial clamping, and consumer goods. These fibers will provide strong reversible adhesive or enhanced shear interfaces that are resistant to contamination and maintain their adhesive ability over the product lifespan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this SBIR Phase II project, the nanoGriptech research team developed methods to manufacture gecko-inspired elastomeric microfiber adhesive arrays using continuous web-based techniques. nanoGriptech's materials are unique in that they consist of arrays of vertically aligned cylindrical structures with enlarged tip shape, as shown in the attached figure. The specific geometric properties of these materials enable a tremendous range of adhesive, frictional, and fastening properties which have been commercialized or are under commercial development in the apparel, automotive, consumer product, aerospace, military, and industrial automation markets, among others. 

The methods developed during this project include the optimization of:

  • Product chemistry
  • Process input chemistries
  • Manufacturing modality
  • Manufacturing process parameters
  • Integration of manufactured materials into customer products

These advances in manufacturing over the duration of this project now allow nanoGriptech to supply gecko-inspired materials in high volume at competitive prices. As a result of these developments, nanoGriptech is now capable of manufacturing parts in high volume with high yield through web-based manufacturing processes, through sheet-based manufacturing processes, and can support the integration of gecko-inspired high friction surfaces into injection-molded parts. Prior to this project, these materials could only be produced in small volumes using time-consuming and expensive micro/nano fabrication techniques.

More broadly, the developed methods are the first, to our knowledge, to commercially manufacture elastomeric micro/nano surfaces with undercut three dimensional features. These techniques could ultimately be adapted to the manufacture of a broad range of micro/nano patterned materials, for example, for self-cleaning or water-repellent surfaces inspired by the naturally-occuring structures on lotus leaves.

Modified by: Paul Glass
